title: Earthquake Preparedness: Shake, Rattle & Ready
description: Learn how to prepare for, survive during, and recover after an earthquake.

sections.title: Before an Earthquake
sections.content:
## Prepare Your Home

- Secure heavy furniture to walls
- Install latches on cabinets
- Know where gas, water, and electricity shutoffs are
- Have an emergency kit ready
- Create a family communication plan
- Identify safe spots in each room (under sturdy tables, against interior walls)

## Emergency Kit Essentials

- Water (1 gallon per person per day for at least 3 days)
- Non-perishable food (at least 3-day supply)
- Battery-powered radio
- Flashlight and extra batteries
- First aid kit
- Whistle to signal for help
- Dust mask, plastic sheeting, and duct tape
- Moist towelettes, garbage bags, and plastic ties
- Wrench or pliers for utilities
- Manual can opener
- Local maps
- Cell phone with chargers and backup battery

sections.title: During an Earthquake
sections.content:
## If You're Inside

- DROP to the ground
- COVER by getting under a sturdy table or desk
- HOLD ON until the shaking stops
- Stay away from windows, outside doors, and walls
- Stay in bed if you're there when an earthquake strikes
- Do not use elevators

## If You're Outside

- Move away from buildings, streetlights, and utility wires
- Once in the open, stay there until the shaking stops

## If You're in a Vehicle

- Stop as quickly and safely as possible
- Avoid stopping near buildings, trees, overpasses, or utility wires
- Stay in the vehicle with seatbelt fastened until shaking stops
- Proceed cautiously after the earthquake has stopped

sections.title: After an Earthquake
sections.content:
## Immediate Actions

- Check yourself and others for injuries
- Inspect your home for damage
- Look for and extinguish small fires
- Clean up spilled medications, bleach, gasoline, or other flammable liquids
- Listen to a battery-operated radio for emergency information

## Safety Precautions

- Expect aftershocks
- Stay away from damaged buildings
- Be careful around broken glass and debris
- Wear sturdy shoes in areas covered with fallen debris and broken glass
- Be careful of chimneys (they may fall during aftershocks)
- Stay away from beaches (tsunami risk)

## When to Evacuate

- If your home is unsafe
- If authorities advise evacuation
- If you're in a tsunami zone after a coastal earthquake
